p.seg: Reforming the Law
Duke Xiao fairly planned,
Gongsun Yang, Gan Long, and Du Zhi, the three high officials, attended the ruler,
contemplating the changes in world affairs,
investigating the foundation of just laws,
and seeking the way to govern the people.
The ruler said:
"To not forget the state and its altars from generation to generation
is the way of a ruler;
to implement laws and strive to make the ruler prominent
is the conduct of a minister.
Now I wish to change the law to govern,
and alter the rituals to teach the people,
but I fear the world will criticize me."
Gongsun Yang said:
"Your servant has heard,
'Hesitant action achieves nothing,
doubtful undertaking accomplishes nothing.'
Your Majesty should quickly decide on reforming the law,
and hardly heed the world's criticism.
Moreover, those who have lofty conduct
are bound to be misunderstood by the world;
those who have uniquely discerning thoughts
will surely be reviled by the people.
The saying goes,
'The foolish are blind to completed matters,
the wise see what is yet to sprout.'
The people cannot be consulted about the beginning,
but they can share in the joy of the accomplishment."
Guo Yan's maxim says:
"He who discusses the highest virtue,
does not harmonize with the common customs;
he who achieves great accomplishments,
does not consult with the multitude."
Law is
that by which the people are loved;
ritual is
that by which affairs are made convenient.
Therefore, if a sage can strengthen the state,
he does not model himself on the past;
if he can benefit the people,
he does not adhere to the rituals."
Duke Xiao said,
"Good."
Gan Long said,
"Not so.
I have heard that
a sage does not change the people in order to teach them,
a wise man does not alter the laws in order to govern.
He who teaches according to the people,
does not labor yet achieves success;
he who governs based on the law,
has officials who are familiar with their duties and people who are at peace.
Now, if you change the law,
not following the customs of the Qin state,
Further, use ritual to teach the people.
Your servant fears that the world will criticize you.
I hope you will carefully consider this."
Gongsun Yang said:
"What you are saying
is the talk of common people.
Common people are comfortable with old habits,
and scholars are mired in what they have heard.
These two types of people are the kind that can hold office and abide by the law,
but they are not the kind to discuss matters beyond the law.
The Three Dynasties attained kingship with different rituals,
and the Five Hegemons attained hegemony with different laws.
Therefore, the wise create laws,
while the foolish are controlled by them;
the worthy change rituals,
while the unworthy are bound by them.
Those bound by ritual
are not worth discussing affairs with;
those controlled by laws
are not worth discussing change with.
Have no doubts, my lord."
Du Zhi said:
"Your servant has heard that
if the benefit is not a hundredfold,
do not change the law;
if the merit is not tenfold,
do not change the tools.
Your servant has heard that there is no fault in following the ancient ways,
Adhering to rituals without deviation.
Your Lordship should consider this."
Gongsun Yang said,
"Previous generations had different teachings.
What ancient law is there to follow?
Emperors and kings did not repeat each other's actions.
What rituals are there to adhere to?
Fuxi and Shennong taught but did not punish.
The Yellow Emperor, Yao, and Shun punished but did not get angry.
As for Wen and Wu,
each established laws according to the times,
and created rituals according to the circumstances.
Rituals and laws are determined by the times.
Decrees and orders should conform to what is appropriate.
Weapons and armor should be prepared for their respective uses.
Therefore, I say,
'Governing the world is not done by one method,
and benefiting the state does not necessarily require following the ancients.'
Tang and Wu became kings
without following the ancients, and thus prospered.
Yin and Xia were destroyed
without changing their rituals, and thus perished.
Therefore, those who oppose the ancient ways cannot necessarily be said to be wrong,
and those who adhere to rituals are not necessarily to be praised.
Your Lordship should have no doubts."
Duke Xiao said,
"Good.
I have heard that strange things are common in remote alleys,
Crooked learning leads to much arguing.
The foolish laugh at it,
while the wise lament it;
the madman rejoices in it,
while the virtuous worry about it.
Confined by worldly views in their discussions,
I, your ruler, have no doubts about this."
Thereupon, he issued an edict to encourage land reclamation.
The Second Edict on Land Reclamation:
If there is no accumulation of affairs left undone overnight,
then corrupt officials will not be able to exploit the people for their own private gain,
and the affairs of the hundred officials will not obstruct each other.
If the affairs of the hundred officials do not obstruct each other,
then the farmers will have extra days.
If corrupt officials cannot exploit the people for their own private gain,
then the farmers will not be exhausted.
If the farmers are not exhausted and have extra days,
then the land will certainly be reclaimed.
Assess grain for taxation,
then the ruler will be unified and the people will be content.
If the ruler is unified, then he will be trustworthy;
if he is trustworthy, then the officials will not dare to be corrupt.
If the people are content, then they will be cautious;
if they are cautious, then they will be difficult to change.
If the ruler is trustworthy and the officials do not dare to be corrupt,
if the people are cautious and difficult to change,
then the lower classes will not criticize the upper classes,
and those in the middle will not suffer from the officials.
If inferiors do not criticize superiors,
and those in the middle ranks do not resent officials,
then strong people will diligently farm without changing.
If strong people diligently farm without changing,
then young people will learn from them tirelessly.
If young people learn from them tirelessly,
then wasteland will surely be cultivated.
If external influence is not used to appoint rank and official positions,
then the people will not value learning and scholarship,
nor will they despise agriculture.
If the people do not value learning, then they will be ignorant.
If they are ignorant, then there will be no foreign affairs.
If there are no foreign affairs, then they will diligently farm and not be lazy.
If the people do not despise agriculture,
then the state will be secure and without danger.
If the state is secure and without danger,
and they diligently farm and are not lazy,
then wasteland will surely be cultivated.
Those with high salaries and heavy taxes,
and many mouths to feed,
are the ruiners of agriculture.
Therefore, according to the number of mouths they feed,
tax them heavily and employ them,
then immoral, wandering, and lazy people will have nowhere to eat.
If they have nowhere to eat, then they will necessarily farm.
If they farm, then wasteland will surely be cultivated.
Cause merchants to be unable to buy grain,
and farmers to be unable to sell grain.
If farmers cannot sell their grain,
then even lazy farmers will strive to work hard.
If merchants cannot buy grain,
then even in plentiful years they will not increase their enjoyment.
If even in plentiful years they do not increase their enjoyment,
then in lean years they will have no surplus profit.
If they have no surplus profit, then merchants will become timid.
If merchants become timid, then they will desire to farm.
If lazy farmers strive to work hard and
merchants desire to farm,
then the land will certainly be cultivated.
If proclamations and decrees do not reach all the counties,
then when the people go out to work, they will not look back,
and when they are at rest, they will not listen [to idle chatter].
If they do not listen [to idle chatter] when at rest,
then their spirits will not be dissipated.
If they do not look back when they go out to work,
then their intentions will certainly be unified.
If their intentions are unified and their spirits are not dissipated,
then the land will certainly be cultivated.
If one cannot obtain laborers,
then the families of high officials will not build or repair.
If beloved sons do not eat idly,
if lazy people are not shiftless,
and if laborers have nowhere to eat,
then they must farm.
If the families of high officials do not build or repair,
then farming will not be harmed.
If sons are loved but do not idly eat,
if lazy people are not allowed to be unproductive,
then old fields will not lie barren.
If agricultural affairs are not harmed,
and farmers become even more diligent in farming,
then wasteland will surely be reclaimed.
If lodging houses are abolished,
then deceitful, reckless, and privately connected people who cause farmers to be suspicious will not travel.
If those who rely on lodging houses have nothing to eat,
then they will surely farm;
if they farm, then wasteland will surely be reclaimed.
If mountain and marsh resources are unified,
then those who dislike farming, are lazy, and desire excessive gain will have nothing to eat;
if they have nothing to eat, then they will surely farm;
if they farm, then wasteland will surely be reclaimed.
Increase the price of wine and meat,
and make their tax heavy,
so that they are ten times as expensive as plain food.
Then merchants and wine sellers will be few,
the people will not be able to indulge in excessive drinking,
and high officials will not indulge in wasteful feasting.
If merchants and wine sellers are few,
then the ruler will not waste grain;
if the people cannot indulge in excessive drinking,
then the farmers will not be lazy;
if high officials do not indulge in wasteful feasting,
then state affairs will not be delayed,
and the ruler will not make excessive actions.
If the ruler does not waste grain,
and the people do not neglect agriculture,
then wasteland will surely be cultivated.
If punishments are made severe and their consequences are extended to related parties,
then narrow-minded and impetuous people will not fight,
stubborn and unyielding people will not litigate,
lazy and indolent people will not wander idly,
extravagant and wasteful people
will not engage in their activities,
and cunning, flattering, and wicked-hearted people will not plot evil.
If these five types of people do not arise within the territory,
then wasteland will surely be cultivated.
If the people are not allowed to move without permission,
then punishing foolish and disruptive farmers will leave them with nowhere to eat, and they will surely farm.
If the foolish, impulsive, and desirous minds of the people are unified,
then the farmers will surely be calm.
If the farmers are calm,
and those who are punished for foolishly disrupting agriculture desire to farm,
then wasteland will surely be cultivated.
Distribute the labor obligations of the surplus sons equally,
and assign them by hereditary succession.
Furthermore, elevate their lodging and accommodations,
ensure they have supplies (甬),
and provide them with standardized rations (概) from the government.
They should not be allowed to evade service.
And if high office is not necessarily attainable,
then the surplus sons will not wander about engaging in affairs.
If the surplus sons do not wander about engaging in affairs,
If they focus on agriculture,
and if they focus on agriculture, then the fields will surely be cultivated.
The great ministers and high officials of the state,
will have no opportunity for broad learning, clever debate, or leisurely living;
all these things will be impossible.
If they cannot reside and travel in the hundred counties,
then the farmers will not hear of changes or see methods from other regions.
If the farmers do not hear of changes or see methods from other regions,
then those who know farming will have no way to depart from their old practices,
and the foolish farmers will not know,
and will not be fond of learning and inquiry.
If the foolish farmers do not know,
and are not fond of learning and inquiry,
then they will diligently apply themselves to farming.
If those who know farming do not depart from their old practices,
then the fields will surely be cultivated.
Order the military markets to have no women,
and command their merchants;
order the people to supply their own armor and weapons,
and make them heed the rise of the army.
Furthermore, order the military markets to have no private transportation of grain,
then treacherous schemes will have nowhere to hide.
Those who secretly transport grain will not be privately investigated.
Light and lazy people will not loiter in the military markets,
those who steal grain will have nowhere to sell it.
Those who deliver grain will not do so privately,
and light and lazy people will not loiter in the military markets,
then the farmers will not be dissolute,
If the state's grain supply is not strained,
then wasteland will surely be reclaimed.
If the governance of all the counties follows a single model,
then those who act circuitously will not embellish,
and those who succeed them will not dare to change the system.
Those who make mistakes and abolish things will not be able to conceal their actions.
If mistaken actions are not concealed,
then there will be no corrupt officials.
If those who act circuitously do not embellish,
and those who succeed them do not change things,
then the number of officials will be small and the people will not be burdened.
If there are no corrupt officials, then the people will not be insolent.
If the people are not insolent,
then their enterprises will not fail.
If the number of officials is small, then levies will not be troublesome.
If the people are not burdened, then farmers will have more time for agriculture.
If farmers have more time for agriculture,
and levies are not troublesome,
and enterprises do not fail,
then wasteland will surely be reclaimed.
If taxes on barriers and markets are heavy,
then farmers will dislike merchants,
and merchants will have suspicious and sluggish hearts.
If farmers dislike merchants,
and merchants are suspicious and sluggish,
then wasteland will surely be reclaimed.
Use the headcount of merchants to employ them,
and order that those who serve as porters and carriers must be registered by name when their loads are heavy.
then farmers are at ease while merchants are toiling.
If farmers are at ease, then good fields will not lie fallow;
If merchants are toiling, then the rituals of sending off and welcoming back will not extend throughout the hundred counties,
then the farmers will not be hungry,
and travelers will not be extravagant.
If the farmers are not hungry,
and travelers are not extravagant,
then public works will surely be swift,
and private works will not be neglected,
then farming affairs will surely be successful.
If farming affairs are surely successful,
then the wasteland will surely be reclaimed.
Order that those transporting grain must not take payment for rental,
and must not return as hired labor;
carts, oxen, and vehicles for heavy loads must be newly equipped,
and must be according to the regulations.
In this case, going will be swift and returning will be quick,
then commerce will not harm agriculture.
If commerce does not harm agriculture,
then the wasteland will surely be reclaimed.
Do not allow (people) to petition officials on behalf of criminals and provide them with food,
then the wicked people will have no support.
If wicked people have no support,
then they will not strive to commit wickedness.
If they do not strive to commit wickedness,
then wicked people will have no means [to carry out their plans].
If wicked people have no means [to carry out their plans],
then the farmers will not be ruined.
If the farmer is not defeated,
then the land will surely be cultivated.
Farmers and Warfare, Part Three
Generally, what rulers use to encourage the people
are official positions and noble ranks;
what a state uses to prosper
are agriculture and warfare.
Now the people seek official positions and noble ranks,
but not through agriculture and warfare,
but through clever words and empty doctrines;
this is called exhausting the people.
A state that exhausts its people
will surely lack strength.
A state that lacks strength
will surely be weakened.
Those who are good at governing a state,
in their instruction of the people,
all obtain official positions and noble ranks through single-minded effort.
Therefore, if not through agriculture and warfare,
then there are no official positions or noble ranks.
If the state abandons rhetoric, then the people will be simple;
if the people are simple, then they will not be licentious.
When the people see that profit comes from single-minded effort,
then they will apply themselves to single-minded effort;
if they apply themselves to single-minded effort, then the people will not be lazy.
If the people are not lazy or licentious, then they will have much strength;
if they have much strength, then the state will be strong.
Now the people within the borders
all say:
"Agriculture and warfare can be avoided,
and official positions and noble ranks can be obtained."
Therefore, heroes and outstanding individuals all change their occupations,
engaging in the study of poetry and books,
and following external powers.
